fixing unit tests for EPMR changes
pulling out hardcoded attributes from EPMR
cleaning non-reusable logic for first binary release
AttributeMap will check the type of each object when setting to determine if it is an AttributeHolder or needs to be wrapped in one.
Raising the sleep time because a user reported failed tests. Perhaps it was due to inaccuracies in the Thread.sleep method?
Shutdown MonitoringEngine before tests to ensure that we are able to override the vmid attribute.
Added reports diretory.
Fixed compilation issues with JDK1.6
Fixing build when log4j isn't included in your jre.
Initial commit

comments.body: I pulled this branch in and called the jar target; the erma-api and erma-lib src jars have the correct files in them, including the appropriate java 5 code.  This looks good to go.

name: spaz-nitrox
description: modified version of Spaz AIR Twitter client, for Nitrox testing

commit.message: - applied patch from David Coallier to integrate short.ie support
- fixed UI binding reference for services-twitpic-sharepassword pref
- added pixel bender libs and effect on opacity change (thanks Remus Stratulat; see http://www.stratulat.com/blog/bended-spaz-a-practical-application-for-pixel-bender)
- added feature to track display replied-to message in tooltip from replies

- changed verifyPassword to only look at status ('successful' call) to determine if succeeded, as per upcoming changes to API. Will need to roll out a 0.6 branch build soon.
- added as3growl.swf and reference to it in trunk; growl notifications only work with Growl 1.1.5, which is in dev currently
hashtag links load search tab when clicked from any tab now
- applied fix for cleared timelines not fully refreshing from branch to trunk
added auto-focus for search field when switching to search tab. A lot of this stuff could use DRYing up and removing all the inline js would help with that, however long it might take to refactor
added hashtag-in-client link-following
tweaked shorten-url dialog: Button is now type="submit" and so Enter key will work for URL submission
added overrideable preference strings (in preferences.json) for 6 features, current defaults are old hard-coded values
brought in latest Introspector/Aliases files from AIR 1.5, which fixes broken ability to tinker in console
- imported sys.js helper into utility windows so openInBrower works properly.
- incremented to version 0.6.0
- items are now marked as read when selected with keyboard.
- moved to version 0.5.8
- removed errant additional definition of check method for timeline-maxentries pref

- minor positioning fix in default theme
- removed some excessive trace dumping
- more updates to help.html because I am stupid

- removed type:'keypress' param from keyboard shortcuts as it seemed to be mucking stuff up on Windows
- more help.html fixes
-corrections/clarifications to help.html

-removed errant return false within keyboard shortcut defs that mucked up stuff on Windows
-added a couple valid chars to link regexes: @#- (had to escape dash)
- upped ceiling for timeline-maxentries to 1000 (default is still 200)

-added char count in ALL themes via hide/show functionality
-moved #entrybox embdedded JS into bindings in Intercept
-changes to friendslist-row templates to pull embedded CSS and add classes
- wilhelm filter is now removed by a timeout, not by a callback at the end of sound playback. Think this will solve issues where it is not reset
- added pref to toggle keyboard nav wraparound in timeline. is now DISABLED by default

- added GUI pref for notification popup location
- fixed bug where users were not warned that password would be shared with twitpic when photo dropped on window
- moved notification prefs into their own section under Interface

- switched various transparent elements to use rgba instead of opacity CSS setting, so child elements are not affected.
- changed positioning calc in purrjs.js to properly position in bottom-left/right
- hitting Enter in username or password pref field now submits new prefs
- hashtags now linked to search.twitter.com

-fixed issues on Windows with notification popups stealing focus
-added a batch script for testing on windows (test.bat)

- fixed a potential security hole in notify window (thanks @doctorlinguist/Cameron Kaiser)
- fixed bug where Enter shortcuts would fire even if form did not have focus (thanks @thynctank/Nick Carter)
- switched back to >> symbol on Spaz menu button
added new string.js helper with escape_html function
- v. minor updates to whitespace theme
- minor css change in whitespace theme

- moved version to 0.5.6
- updated whitespace theme w/ new design
- changed symbol after "Spaz" header button
- some minor lib and CSS changes to get username suggestions positioned correctly.

- updated and redesigned spaz-mini theme
- removed some file cruft

- Updated Dumb Terminal theme to work with new html
- reduced size of all themes' images

- added stub for handling invoke events in spaz.intercept.js
- changed RT text a little to save a char and remove quotes
- version 0.5.5

- integrated new userCompleter library to add username completion in entrybox. Still needs positioning work
- added retweet feature with new tiny icon
- incremented to version 0.5.4
- restored jquery.array.js plugin, which fixes followers/following sections
- fixed a bug where template was not parsed properly for DMs

- fixed references to jquery.js in some popup windows
- incremented version to 0.5.3
- changed most event listeners back from weak ref to strong refs, and added remove statements for async sql calls

- fixed some keyboard scrolling problems
- added wrapper to prefs timeline

- ho ho ho, favorite stars now get filled-in properly!
- panel menus now stay at top of panel -- don't scroll with timeline (only works in default theme for now)

- version 0.5.2
- added "mark" buttons to timeline menus
- fixed <label> for attributes (thx thynctank)
- small css adjustment to fit filter textbox in timeline menu
- removed some unnecessary window.activate() code
- modified PurrJS.notify to use visible property of nativeWindow to avoid stealing focus from main window

Lots of keyboard nav improvements
- fixed regression where timeline didn't scroll with keyboard movement caused by change in what element is doing the scrolling
- keyboard movement now only scrolls when selected item is below bottom or above top of scrolling element
- keyboard movement is now limited to only visible items
- keyboard movement now works on all timelines
- changed hide/show method on filtering to use .hidden class, so dm/reply toggling is not interfered with

- fixed links to js libs in HTML popup windows
- added realtime filtering for friends, user and public timelines
- hooked up refresh and toggle buttons in timeline menus
- added menus to each content panel
- Fixed introspector path lib in Spaz.Debug.insertDebugScripts
- restructured the assets directory to make things moderately less messy.
- reorganized the prefs HTML
- removed dock-refresh-interval because no longer relevant (using event triggering)
add "wilhelm-enabled" feature -- turns Wilhelm scream/effect on/off

- changed a little verbage in the status bar to explain why your app is unresponsive
- changed default location of window to 50x50 (250x250 was ridiculous)

- added urlzen.com shortlink support
- refactored sorting again. Does a check to see if timeline is already in proper order before resorting; faster in most cases
- refactored cleanupTimeline a lot, moving many aspects into addItemToTimeline. Seems to increase speed slightly
- added ~ to valid char in URI paths, so blip.fm links now work
- added support for https in URL auto-linking

- refactored sorting a little to drop need for jquery.array plugin
- added back time reporting calls for dev purposes
- code reformatting in a number of files.
version 0.5.1

- refactored several simple functions to exist inside the helpers folder/files
- re-used Spaz.Menus to get context menus for Dock and systray icons
- added Quit and Reset position items to dock/systray context menus
- made some windowing event listeners strong referenced so we don't have issues with them disappearing
- moved a number of functions into helper files
- renamed types.js to javascript.js
- implemented Spaz.Timers timer queue class, tried to use this to make long-running stuff non blocking. limited success. Queue is still of value, though
- Fix to notifications to show # of new messages - 1, as it's meant to read as "New message from this user, plus XX more"
- dropped tag.js-based autocomplete; will likely need to rewrite it entirely.
fix for Issue 78 "Tweets should be marked as read when they are highlighted"
- changed jquery/tag.js to use $('body').intercept instead of binding click events. Hoping this helps with memleaks/slowdowns in typing

- changed almost all AIR event listeners to use weak references, allowing them to be garbage collected. Optimistic this 
should help memory leakage considerably. This has broken async writes to the DB at the moment, though (anonymous callbacks 
and weak references don't fly, I think)
- replaced as3notificationlib with pure HTML/JS notification system
- port of fixes from 0.4.6 branch to trunk

- version 0.4.6.3 on 0.4.6 branch
- modified main timeline section to use since_id instead of since parameter. This should fix problems where users were missing tweets if local and server time were not in sync
- removed time.* calls in 0.4.6 branch
- ported fix for timeline-entry.tpl for entry-id attribute from 0.4.6 branch
- Enter in #search-for now starts search
- set trunk version to 0.5.0

- applied bugfix for dirs not existing on startup to trunk
- added code to init.css to elimintate select-ability in everything except form text fields and status text
oops : bug introduced in previous commit
inline the padding and border constants instead of being on Spaz.Dock since we won't make that configurable at all

- improved text drawing by using a better bounding box detection algorithm
- added configurable colors
- added a new badge shape (star)
- improve the classic badge rendition
- 0.4.6.0. screwed up by using 0.4.4 (no trailing .0) on last release, can't push out 0.4.4.1. Have to jump to 0.4.6.0.

- version 0.4.4.1
- updated themes to be in-line with the default one regarding positioning of search menu, user avatars fade-in, Spaz>> button highlighting
- added data to delete entry action so it forces a post
- forgot to add new BG shown while avatar loads

- Now passing template path as an identifier to the tpl parser, so cached tpl objects can be retrieved correctly
- Set up fade-in of user avatars on load event for the img. Really shouldn't add shit like this so late.

- rename Spack.dock ->  Spaz.Dock for consistency
- if the image is not loaded yet, don't perform the refresh
- version 0.4.3.6 (so I don't get confused)

- Added Spaz.UI.getUnreadCount() to retrieve current unread count in main timeline. 
- made Spaz.dock use Spaz.UI.getUnreadCount()
- minor default theme change to make Spaz>> button more obvious. I hope.
- more speedups on rendering. Added a minor change to the timeline-entry.tpl that saves us extra jqueries and saves about 100ms on refreshes

- Speed optimizations on template rendering when new content is added to timelines
- timing code is being left in for the time being

- moved to version 0.4.3.5. this may not be the one that's released as test, tho.
- removed all calls to Spaz.Cache.buildScreenNameCache
- refactored Spaz.Cache.getScreenNamesAsTags a little
- removed a number of air.trace calls that weren't necessary anymore
- refactored get_relative_time() some and shortened the strings returned considerably
- did a bunch of profiling stuff with the time.js library to try to speed up refreshes
- moved to a template-based layout for timeline entries. This actually slows stuff down a bit, and I'm a little worried about memory consumption. Templates would be a big win in terms of layout flexibility, though.
- rewrote Spaz.Tpl.parse to use the Trimpath template system; now using it to process templates in one line
- removed a ton of commented-out code from spaz.ui.js
- refactored sorting algorithms to only sort *new* messages, speeding up process considerably.
- changed layout of index.html some to better handle the search timeline, which has it's #search-menu. Also added code to default theme to handle new layout. Other themes still need to be adjusted.

- add JSON parser wrapper that will help to debug JSON parsing issues and most importantly fix JSON corrupted data returned by Twitter
- use the JSON parser in the timeline to remove corrupted data from Twitter and display data as most as it is possible (best effort basis)

- fixed/modified the .check() method for the dock-refreshinterval pref so it always assumes value is a string
- added "assets/helpers" section to contain libaries of procedural-ish functions for simple tasks. Initial one is for detecting data types ("isString()")
- messed a bit with the timeline-entry.tpl
a bit of documentation
tweak to look like adium badge
improve visual appearance of the unread badge by using a better boxing method for the unread text graphics
added preferences for dock
remove obsolete code
make the unread count to be periodically refreshed
started support for OSX icon dock notifications, does not do anything for now as it is not wired to the runtime
- version 0.4.3.3

- added CSS to remove ugly webkit focus rings around elements.
- updated default theme to add yellow bg highlighting to text form fields on focus
- added keystroke (CMD+SHIFT+,) to open preferences folder. This should allow user to access prefs files more easily when UI is hosed by bad CSS
- added check for services-twitpic-sharepassword to determine if confirm popup should be shown when image dropped on app
- twitter-compatible API prefs GUIs all set up
- sections now reload their own URLs on each build when appropriate, in case API urls have changed
- click event on #prefs-open-folder is now handled by spaz.intercept.js
- prefs are now saved just before an update is applied
better support for twitpic : makes an ajax request to get the twitpic real URL since we cannot assume twitpic will use jpg format
add support for twitpic thumbnail preview in the tooltip

- Made $.ajaxes actually use POST by giving it data to pass in the POST payload
- added Spaz.Data.makeNotFavorite method
- version 0.4.3.3

- fix where error would result if ping.fm user key was not set
- now using encodeURIparam to try to encode since UTC date properly. If this doesn't work, going to drop since support for now
- added GUI elements for Other Services. none but Ping.fm work so far.
- changed several actions in spaz.data.js to POST due to vulnerability patches in Twitter API.
- Since param now generated with new Date().toUTCString(); this should be RFC-822 compliant and work properly in future.

- added GUI for ping.fm preferences
- implemented necessary methods for ping.fm preferences
- changed "since" date format to isoUtcDateTime; hopefully will work better for non-US users

- FIXED: User CSS is now loaded AFTER theme files, so proper overriding is possible
- User CSS <link> element is now generated by Spaz.Themes.init();
- added ping.fm to list of URL shorteners to replace inline. I hope this is fine for non-shortening URLs.
- Version 0.4.3.2. Oops.

- version 0.4.3.1
- Added Spa.DB.markEntryAsRead() to a few places that weren't being tracked
- Added functionality to open the ApplicationStorage directory in the Finder. Hope it works in Windows too.
- Added Spaz.UI.getStatusIdFromElement() method to obtain status_id more easily
Added persistence implementation of entries marked as read that will be shown as read on the next application reload

- changed screen_name autocompletion to *not* cache names. Hoping this will improve performance. Need feedback on this.
- changed URLs to all be pref-based - twitter-api-base-url and twitter-base-url. This should allow users to use alternate services with the same API, like Identi.ca. Right now you need to manually edit your preferences.json file.
- Moved placement of initNetworkConnectivityCheck and added initMemcheck to track memory usage, but neither seem to run properly -- still! Maybe air.Timer objects just don't work in JS apps?

- ALL tweets - not just non-replies/dms - are deleted from end when timeline space is exceeded. partly for aesthetics, partly because it could be a memleak.
- Change to RFC822 mask in date.format.js to correctly display TZ info in non-US locales. This fixes bug where post-initial refreshes wouldn't show any new posts
- added initial support for reposting to ping.fm. @replies and dms are NOT reposted. To enable, must set prefs manually in preferences.json, including services-pingfm-userappkey and services-pingfm-enabled
- moved file uploading into Spaz.Data to better segregate actions
- tweaked tooltip hiding to only be done by intercept, not with binding at end of showing; thought it might be a mem leak, but prob not.
- set useCache and cacheResponse on htmlLoader and urlrequests to TRUE; shouldn't be a problem, and might speed things up
- moved all the short URL service methods to Spaz.Shortlink.services so they can be iterated over without worry of polluting the namespace and junk
- added a 'mark_as_read" param to Spaz.UI.addItemToTimeline so that certain messaged (like ones you post) aren't marked as new or read. Should keep them from raising notifications

- version 0.4.3.0
- drag and drop uploading to Twitpic: added code to spaz.intercept to handle dragged&dropped image file uploading to Twitpic. This s
hould be polished up; there is a popup window UI that should be used in the future
- refactored section.friends_timeline to initially load 100 messages, then use since parameter after initial load. Seems to increase
 responsiveness of refreshes after initial
- added alphabetical sorting to friends and followers lists
- some UI changes via CSS and template to friends/followers lists
- iPhone: long/lat codes are now cleaned up and link properly from friends/follower entries
- added some settings/prefs for Ping.fm support. No real code done yet
- changed Spaz.Sys.initNetworkConnectivityCheck() to use help/test API method, and changed check interval to 1min. This isn't really
 used yet, but could be easily.
- refactored spaz.section to be wrapped in an init() method
- redid jquery-ui theme. Not sure if it will be used
- added an app descriptor for AIR1.0 so building for the sucky Linux alpha is easier.

- version 0.4.2.1
- rudimentary Twitpic upload working, disabled in this release
- some groundwork for Ping.fm support (app key pref)
- added bit.ly shortening, decoding support
- fixed wonkiness with API rate limit/refresh rate adjustment so whole #s are always calculated, and won't accidentally exceed API slightly
- recoded HTML and adjusted CSS of themes so all theme images are now controlled by CSS
- added file for timeline-entry.tpl; not used yet, still needs coding

- version 0.4.2.0
- auto-refresh rate changing also changes friends section mincachetime

- Version 0.4.1.1
- Now requires AIR 1.1. Should gain AIR 1.1 advantages (like extended language support)
- Added decoding for xrl.us; added xrl.us to available shortlink services
- Tweaks so getRateLimitInto will not run if username or password is not set.
- rate limit info will auto-set refresh rate whenever username/pass is verified, if pref is enabled.

- Added code to retrieve rate limit from Twitter; set rate automatically
- Added pref to set refresh rate automatically on startup
- Fixes to buggy code so notification popups on Twitter errors contain the exact message Twitter returned (and indicates that Twitter is telling us this)
- Made several changes to error messages to make it clearer when Server returns errors
- did a very little bit of work on getting Spaz.Update to check for regular versions after test versions are checked

- refactored tooltip code a lot to move it into a more proper OOP setup, and add a short delay before display. Should fix many problems with overwriting/disappearing previews in tooltips
- added a couple more "hidden" prefs, related to tooltips and such, and one to determine if data is auto-loaded into timeline on startup.

- added option in URL Shortener to choose service. Is.gd is now the default.
- removed unused spaz.info.js
- fixed bug in menu for Shorten URL...

- added new short URL decoding code by @julienviet
- added new domains to decode: "is.gd","snipr.com","snurl.com","moourl.com","url.ie","snipurl.com"

- version 0.4.1.0
- added menu item for link shortener
- Version 0.4.0.0

- Version 0.4.0
- added JulienViet to contributors list
- changed help to reflect CMD+7 tab shortcut

- version 0.3.9.4
- minor change in Spaz.Debug.dump to handle missing Spaz.Prefs without throwing error
- User CSS now works properly. is saved in appstore:/user.css
- Removed stuff related to theme-userstylesheet pref UI and entry
- Changed labels on Prefs UserCSS load and edit buttons
- Added Spaz.Sys.setFileContents to write strings to a given file
- Boostrapping now loads user.css
- Added support for inline TinyURL decoding (thanks @julienviet)
- added very simplistic limiting/deleting to screen_name cache

- app version now 0.3.9.2
- fixed double-encoding bug with summize searches; now can use all operators, search for multiple terms
- moved CSS for .search-menu into themes dirs from init.css; made per-theme alterations
- cleaned up CSS for prefs in Whitespace and others
- moved context menu stuff into spaz.intercept.js
- added help button to search form that opens http://summize.com/operators
- removed windows.css; no longer used
- resized and re-exported spaz theme images to avoid HTML scaling and reduce size
- added jquery-ui theme to spaz theme for future use

- Moved event delegation to Spaz.Intercept.init()
- Added calculation of # reqs/hour next to refresh interval pref UI
- Search section now clears results only if search term is new since last search
- Added info to About on "media sets used" (sound and emoticon sets)
- Upgraded to newest jquery.intercept.js
- Shortened some prefs UI labels to avoid overflow; reduced padding of Prefs panelset

- added bridge to classic sandbox via hidden iframe. Not happy to have to do this, but necessary for templating system
- added templating parsing, used in friends and followers list. Will expand to others. Using Trimpath template system
- Summize-powered searching cleanups; operators like to:screen_name and from:screen_name now work
- forgot to check-in the new jquery and highlighting plugin

- deleted jQuery-UI stuff
- upgraded to jQuery 1.2.6
- removed animation queuing plugin because of conflicts with jQuery. Wasn't using it anyway
- Got Summize-powered searching in a usable state
- Removed other unused or unnecessary JQ plugins
- Made tabs in default theme smaller
- set minimum width for app window at 280px. Maybe too wide for other themes?
- made menu item for Preferences
- login panel in prefs now delays opening by 500ms to fix Spry bug
- Added menu item, keyboard shortcut (CMD+SHIFT+R) to mark all as read in a timeliine
- Refactored selecting entry code (Spaz.UI.SelectEntry)
- Refactored tooltip code to maybe keep wrong "previews" from showing up in a tooltip
- Spaz.UI.addItemTimeline now checks for .error property; logs if present

- Changed userAgent to have Spaz/[version] instead of AIR/[version]
- Added initial code for Twitter connectivity check. Just dumps status when it changes. Checks every 15 seconds.
- Got User CSS editor working. Changes are not saved on exit, however
- Moved Spaz.UI.clearUserStyleSheet to Spaz.Themes
- Added pref saving to Spaz.Windows.onWindowClose(). Fixes bug where prefs not saved on OS X CMD+Q exit
- removed a bunch of unused jquery libs (enchant, ui extras)

Version 0.3.8.0 release

- updated copyright years in LICENSE.txt
- changed timeout on updating to 40secs
- Updater now will check for tests versions instead of release versions if preference is set
- updated what's new
- added json update descriptor
Fixed bug where clicking on the avatar in the friends or followers lists would open the URL within Spaz.
Updated whatsnew.html

Release 0.3.7.4 - Test version
- added basics for searching via Summize.com. Tab for this is commented-out, though. You can re-enable by editing index.html and uncommenting if you wish
- added check to see if pref set for updating on startup before actually updating on startup
- added pref for checking for test versions during update. This isn't handled in the updating code itself, though
- added pref for scrolling to top on refresh
- updated What's New
- some cosmetic changes to prefs UI
- commented-out "Post..." menu item; this won't be used in 0.3.8
- minor tweaks to CSS for utility windows
- fixed/added JS libs to utility windows so there is consistency; also added prefs mapping to main window
- Added lists of contributors, donors, and updated list of libraries to About window

- Auto-updating completely recoded and working. This version should be able to detect, download and install subsequent versions
- Turned on auto-loading of friends timeline at startup

- Switched back to jquery.intercept.1.0.2 due to problems with event object not appearing in callbacks. Will investigate
- fixed bug where Wilhelm would not undo itself if sound was not enabled. Now do not fire Wilhelm if sound is disabled (that was easy)
- removed KeyboardHandler for document.onkeydown, which was only used to bind 'Enter' to sending the message when entryBox has focus -- sending is now handled by shortcut setups
- added hidden pref for twitter-source string. This allows users change the source string as they like. Mainly here so people don't have to announce that they use Spaz in countries where it's considered a highly offensive slur, but you could also use it to pretend you're a cool kid who uses Twhirl when you really love Spaz more
- messed around a LOT with shutdown event handling stuff that accomplished absolutely nothing. The shutdown sound makes this much, much more complicated than it would be without it. Wondering if its worth it.
- Changed the version # in application.xml to 0.3.7.1-SVN12. My versioning system is completely random.

- updated jquery.scrollTo and jquery.intercept to newest versions (thx Ariel Flesler)
- fixed bug where loaded prefs were skipped if the value of the key was false
- fixed bug where app would not exit properly if CMD+Q used and sound was disabled. Now, though, shutdown sound does not play if enabled and CMD+Q used. Don't care; let's call it a "fast exit" feature.
- fixed up path problem where jquery was not loading properly in help.html; this fixes prob where version info would not load
- commented-out any calls to Updater until that portion of code is ready to be tested properly
- changed Spaz.Windows.exitCalled to Spaz.Windows.windowExitCalled to make clearer that it only is true when app is exiting due to the main window being closed. I have no idea if this will actually be used, though.
- added a couple more links to about.html and removed link to Firebug lite (which is not used anymore)
- cleaned up css_edit.html a little. This is still not actually being used
- changed refs from spaz.info.js to spaz.sys.js in all .html windows

- cleaned out the spaz.sys.js object and moved its methods to spaz.info.js
- added jsdocs to spaz.data.js
- refactored most ajax calls in spaz.data.js to use a couple common methods for error and complete
- added sendDM, sendReply, followSpaz menu items to main menu
- added check to enable keyboard shortcuts in Linux (thanks agolna)
- total reimplementation of Updater system. Might even work when it's done
- some tweaks to Spaz.UI.prep* to handle new menu items for replies and DMs better
- renamed Spaz.Data.onAjaxComplete to Spaz.Data.onSectionAjaxComplete so the generic onAjaxComplete handler could use the name
- fixed bug where suggestions plugin wasn't re-initialized when main timeline loaded.

Added screen_name completion in entrybox
- added building of screen name cache in Spaz.Cache
- screen names built from main timeline and friends/followers lists
- using a modified tag.js jquery plugin (del.icio.us-style tag suggestions)
- changed mainmenu behavior to do a closeAll whenever an item is clicked.

- fixed some issues where emoticons using < or > did not display (had to use htmlentities instead)
- tweaking of main menu css to get separators looking good and link areas display:block
- removed error popup notification on empty responses from twitter (can get these if no replies or dms are present)
- re-enabled creation of systray icon on Windows (not tested yet)
- now fading in/out body and not just #container or startup/shutdown
- fixed missing + in tooltips for tabs
- added interceptors for menu items: about, help, view>toggle/reload/clear and reload
- added interceptor for directory-user-location
- removed animations on hiding/showing because they interfered with proper timeline filter toggling
- fixed bug where .once events were not unbound from previous appearances of context menu
- fixed bug where ^C to force exit would throw app into an infinite loop
- Added links in help menu to Spaziki, user group, code site
- a couple minor enhancements to utilitywindow.css
- removed help and about buttons (now items in main menu)
- changes to followers/following templates to re-enable click on location > Yahoo! map
- Changes to Spaz header to better indicate its clickability (mimics window-buttons)

- added parsing of simplesmileys thx to Graeme Dunlop <http://twitter.com/@kbitzer>
- Gmail smileys also in code, but switching/prefs not supported yet
- added creation of usersmileys dir in prefs dir on startup

- Some fixes to tooltips so that only one unique "preview" section is written to
- cleaned up Followers/Following lists; removed action placeholders b/c context menus do well enough

- added visual wilhelm excitement
- now uses ajaxy tooltip to retrieve user data in all situations
- added maximum # of entries limit to try to prevent slowdowns. controlled by pref timeline-maxentries. default is 200
- slideDowns and slideUps were too slow with more than a few timeline entries when toggling filtering. Switched to fades
- TONS of work on the tooltips stuff to avoid double-prepending of tooltip previews/user data. Think it's working better now
- Dropped now-unnecessary "popupStr" embedded in entries when added to timeline
- fixed up CSS that was causing protected updates icon to float weirdly
- fixes so @username tooltips still function correctly, as well as still giving us user context menus
- added user context menu to inline @username links within tweets

- Added currently-useless "system menu" that appears when clicking on "Spaz" in header; uses jquery.menu.js
- fixes to intercept selectors that fix bug where user menus appears *everywhere*
- added check in Spaz.UI.showUserContextMenu() where return false if screen_name is not valid

- added jquery.fxqueues.js to handle sequential animations
- added supression of notification when just-posted status has been added to timeline
- added new user context menus
- made openInBrowser() an alias for Spaz.Sys.openInBrowser()
- added shortcuts for tabs 5 and 6 (cmd/ctrl+[5-6])
- changed timeline filtering to animate hiding/showing of tweets. Necessary because of new animation method of revealing newly added tweets would override cascading style from container DIV
- added "queue:false" to all jquery.animate() calls to avoid erroneous queuing
- renamed "Spaz.UI.showContextMenu" to "Spaz.UI.showLinkContextMenu" and added matching "Spaz.UI.showUserContextMenu"
- added more checks in Spaz.UI.addItemToTimeline() for building the popupStr and avoiding nulls. Also fixed bug where \' would show up
- newly added timeline items now appear via queued slideDown FX, not fading in.
- added in *all* of the jquery enchant alpha libs. This seems like overkill.
- added HTML for #userContextMenu in index.html
- removed binding in Spaz.UI.cleanupTimeline for contentmenus (DUH DUH DUH) and moved to intercept setup in Spaz.init()

- fixed param order bug copying new shortlinks to clipboard

- changed fadein time on app startup to 1000ms

- completely reformatted and cleaned-up Spaz theme CSS file to make it easier to understand. Still needs a bit more work.

- re-enabled followers and friends listings. currently only list first 100. tablesorter plugin uses eval, so doesn't sort. Will need more cleanup; may drop sorting.
- used templating system for followers directory. Should extend this to other repeating sections
- debugging now toggles whether or not AIRintrospector is included or not

- added jquery enchant fx libs

- tooltips now hide when window is deactivated
- messed a lot (again) with link parsing to get it to work correctly and not have markdown step on other parsers' toes

- removed firebug

- finally got shutdown after sound playback working

- switched debugging to use pref, not a touched file
- refactored some windows names
- started sending Spaz.dump output to AIRIntrospector console when debugging enabled
- sounds play properly now
- moved and trimmed a ton of Spry stuff

-- big checkin, lots of changes. 
- prefs system totally rewritten and simplified. JSON now used for storage; XML support dropped entirely. Prefs system now much simpler, much easier to expand.
- You will probably need to re-enter your prefs -- I don't think a migration system is worth the trouble
- major refactoring of prefs data handling; everything is stored in a JS object, and must be accessed from it.  Many properties like Spaz.UI.*** have been removed entirely
- paths to sound files now stored in preferences.json. Can be manually altered by user. Still relative to app for now (this needs to be changed)
- Updating prefs through the UI is still shakey, and needs more work. Some stuff works, some doesn't
- Switching/clicking on tabs will no longer reload the timeline if you're under the minimum time to refresh. This is 3 minutes for main timeline, different for others. Still can force a refresh with F5.
- added initial creation of user-space themes and plugins directories. themes *can* be read from the user themes dir. This means user-created themes will survive app updates
- speaking of updates, the updater is totally broken and should be rewritten mostly from scratch
- Firebug has been dropped entirely now. AIRInspector can be brought up with CMD+1. Probably need to only load this when debugging is enabled, tho
- When a tweet is unselected, it is "marked as read" and assigned the "read" class. Spaz default theme supports this. Maybe need to add "mark all as read" feature.
- verify_credentials now uses json, because non-formatted version was flaking out while coding. Fixed now, but JSON is probably better
- Added JSON2.js lib for serializing and decoding JSON
- lots of cleanup in Spaz.init to make it smaller, more modular
- lots of stuff removed from Spaz.Handlers because it's a stupid namespacing idea
- lots of crap moved from Spaz.UI to Spaz.Windows|Keyboard|et al because UI was becoming a dumping ground for everything
- deleted Spaz.Bridge entirely. Thank god.

-- deleted old jquery 1.2.1, jquery-ui.min
-- added jquery.ui 1.5 beta (this will need to get trimmed down for proper release)
-- moved about, help and link shortener windows to separate windows opened with window.open
-- modified link shortening to be more modular, automatically detect and convert links in clipboard
-- Some crap. I dunno. I'm too tired to talk about it. Diff this shit if you really care.

name: js-slideengine
description: A simple slideshow engine that should allow JavaScript demonstrations.
readme:
js-slideEngine
==============
Simple, HTML-based presentations - with JavaScript
--------------------------------------------------

The target user is a web developer presenting in front of an audience at a conference, meet-up, meeting, etc.

The goals for js-slideengine are (most important first):
* Work in Gecko/FireFox (done)
* PageUp/PageDown slide navigation (done)
* Allow in-slide editing and execution of JavaScript (done)
* Resolution independence (done)
* HTML simplicity (done)
* Look good (working on it)
* Work in WebKit/Safari/Chrome (tested in Chrome)
* Work in IE (not even close - oh well)

Instructions for Use
--------------------

1. Copy or rename template.html
2. Edit the HTML file, giving each slide the "slide" class
3. `<jeffgoldblum>`There's no step three`</jeffgoldblum>`

### Little Details

* Use textareas for your JavaScript code.
* To avoid strange browser behavior on page reload, give each textarea a unique name.
* Aforementioned text areas are automatically formatted to take the top half of the screen and are given "Go" buttons that will `eval()` their contents.
* Any slide that contains just one element will have that element automatically centered.

name: deep_cloning
readme:
= Deep Cloning Plugin

This plugin gives every ActiveRecord::Base object the possibility to do a deep clone.

Repository is on github: http://github.com/DefV/deep_cloning/tree/master

Install with:
  script/plugin install git://github.com/DefV/deep_cloning.git

== Example

=== Cloning a model without an attribute
   pirate.clone :except => :name
 
=== Cloning a model without multiple attributes
   pirate.clone :except => [:name, :nick_name]
=== Cloning one single association
   pirate.clone :include => :mateys

=== Cloning multiple associations
   pirate.clone :include => [:mateys, :treasures]

=== Cloning really deep
   pirate.clone :include => {:treasures => :gold_pieces}

=== Cloning really deep with multiple associations
   pirate.clone :include => [:mateys, {:treasures => :gold_pieces}]
Copyright (c) 2008 Jan De Poorter, released under the MIT license

commit.message: Polly wants a patcher

Cloning really deep with multiple associations

Made it easy to do deep cloning with multiple associations. So you could do:
	pirate.clone :include => [:mateys, {:treasures => :gold_pieces}]

thanks to Mark Donnelly for this patch

name: shoulda
description: Makes tests easy on the fingers and the eyes
readme:
= Shoulda - Making tests easy on the fingers and eyes

Shoulda makes it easy to write elegant, understandable, and maintainable tests.  Shoulda consists of test macros, assertions, and helpers added on to the Test::Unit framework.  It's fully compatible with your existing tests, and requires no retooling to use.

Helpers:: #context and #should give you rSpec like test blocks.
          In addition, you get nested contexts and a much more readable syntax.
Macros:: Generate hundreds of lines of Controller and ActiveRecord tests with these powerful macros.
         They get you started quickly, and can help you ensure that your application is conforming to best practices.
Assertions:: Many common rails testing idioms have been distilled into a set of useful assertions.

= Usage

=== Context Helpers (Shoulda::Context)

Stop killing your fingers with all of those underscores...  Name your tests with plain sentences!

  class UserTest < Test::Unit::TestCase
    context "A User instance" do
      setup do
        @user = User.find(:first)
      end

      should "return its full name" do
        assert_equal 'John Doe', @user.full_name
      end

      context "with a profile" do
        setup do
          @user.profile = Profile.find(:first)
        end

        should "return true when sent #has_profile?" do
          assert @user.has_profile?
        end
      end
    end
  end

Produces the following test methods:

  "test: A User instance should return its full name."
  "test: A User instance with a profile should return true when sent #has_profile?."

So readable!

=== ActiveRecord Tests (Shoulda::ActiveRecord::Macros)

Quick macro tests for your ActiveRecord associations and validations:

  class PostTest < Test::Unit::TestCase
    fixtures :all

    should_belong_to :user
    should_have_many :tags, :through => :taggings

    should_require_unique_attributes :title
    should_require_attributes :body, :message => /wtf/
    should_require_attributes :title
    should_only_allow_numeric_values_for :user_id
  end

  class UserTest < Test::Unit::TestCase
    should_have_many :posts

    should_not_allow_values_for :email, "blah", "b lah"
    should_allow_values_for :email, "a@b.com", "asdf@asdf.com"
    should_ensure_length_in_range :email, 1..100
    should_ensure_value_in_range :age, 1..100
    should_protect_attributes :password
  end

Makes TDD so much easier.

=== Controller Tests (Shoulda::Controller::Macros)

Macros to test the most common controller patterns...

  context "on GET to :show for first record" do
    setup do
      get :show, :id => 1
    end

    should_assign_to :user
    should_respond_with :success
    should_render_template :show
    should_not_set_the_flash

    should "do something else really cool" do
      assert_equal 1, assigns(:user).id
    end
  end

=== Helpful Assertions (Shoulda::Assertions)

More to come here, but have fun with what's there.

  assert_same_elements([:a, :b, :c], [:c, :a, :b])
  assert_contains(['a', '1'], /\d/)
  assert_contains(['a', '1'], 'a')

=== 3rd Party and Application Specific Macros

Any *.rb file under RAILS_ROOT/test/shoulda_macros/ or vendor/(plugins|gems)/gem_name/shoulda_macros/ will be automatically required when you run your tests.  This allows you to distribute macros with your plugins, or to organize the macros inside your application.  Remember to add your macro to Test::Unit::TestCase in the macro file:

  # test/shoulda_macros/security.rb
  class Test::Unit::TestCase
    def self.should_be_denied(opts = {})
      should_set_the_flash_to(opts[:flash] || /Please log in/i)
      should_redirect_to(opts[:redirect]   || 'login_url')
    end
  end

= Rails Installation

=== As a Gem

Use this if you prefer to use versioned releases of shoulda.  Specify the gem dependency in your config/environment.rb file:

  Rails::Initializer.run do |config|
    config.gem "thoughtbot-shoulda", :lib => "shoulda", :source => "http://gems.github.com"
  end

Then:

  $ rake gems:install
  $ rake gems:unpack

=== As a Plugin

Use this if you prefer to use the edge version of shoulda:

  $ script/plugin install git://github.com/thoughtbot/shoulda.git

=== As a Plugin (using git submodules)

Use this if you prefer the idea of being able to easily switch between using edge or a tagged version of shoulda:

  $ git submodule add git://github.com/thoughtbot/shoulda.git vendor/plugins/shoulda

= Credits

Shoulda is maintained by {Tammer Saleh}[mailto:tsaleh@thoughtbot.com], and is funded by Thoughtbot[http://www.thoughtbot.com], inc.

= License

Shoulda is Copyright  2006-2008 Tammer Saleh, Thoughtbot. It is free software, and may be redistributed under the terms specified in the MIT-LICENSE file.

name: librebecca
readme:
------------------------------------------------------------------

* WELCOME!

This is the RebeccaAIML Project.  

RebeccaAIML is an enterprise cross platform open source 
AIML development platform. RebeccaAIML supports C++, Java,
C#, and Python as well as many other programming languages
and AIML development out of the box.  RebeccaAIML also 
comes with an array of AIML administration tools, great 
documentation, and an eclipse AIML editor plugin. 

{ From the redistributor: 

## NOTE: This distrobution is not the official RebeccaAIML
project, but a re-distrobution for GNU/Linux users, because 
the authors source code was written in Visual Studio and didn't
play well with modern Linux machines. This source has been
successfully tested on Ubuntu and Gentoo machines, with only
standard Ubuntu .debs and standard Gentoo .ebuilds.

HOWEVER, This is not the authors release, the last release from
the original author was in 2007.

}

------------------------------------------------------------------

* AUTHOR and LICENSE

Frank Hassanabad : foreverlinux@yahoo.com
Drop me an email if you have any problems.

See 'copyright' about the GPLv3 licence in which 
this project is covered.

------------------------------------------------------------------

* PROGRAMMING WITH THE API AND FRAMEWORK

So how do you start programming with the API and/or framework?  
For a quick start check out the source code of the samples.  
you'll find them under [src\samples]. 

------------------------------------------------------------------

* THE DOCUMENTATION OF THE APIs AND FRAMEWORK

Where's the full documentation of the APIs and FRAMEWORK at?  You can 
find the documentation of the api and framework in the [doc] directory.
under Linux that's  [/usr/share/librebecca/doc]

You can also find more documentation at the RebeccaAIML website: 
http://rebecca-aiml.sourceforge.net/documentation.htm

------------------------------------------------------------------

* COMPILING THE SOURCE CODE OF THE ENGINE

I want to compile the complete source code of the engine and not 
just the samples.  How do I do that?

[/usr/share/librebecca/doc/linuxInstall.txt] for Linux.

------------------------------------------------------------------

* DESCRIPTION OF ALL THE DIRECTORIES AND FILES

Can you give me an overview of all the files and directories of 
RebeccaAIML?  Under Windows these files are located at 
[<wherever_you_installed>\...] and under Linux these files are 
located at [/usr/share/Rebecca]

If you have the source or binary distribution you
have the following directories of:

[aiml]      Varoius AIML data sets that are included 
            with the RebeccaAIML distribution and used 
			by the samples.

[conf]      Various configuration files that the samples
            use when they load.

[doc]       Where all the documentation is located. 
            Everything from the API documentation, user guide,
            to how to install Rebecca from full source 
            code is here.

[include]   All the include files for building against 
            RebeccaAIML with C++.  
            			
[resources] Various resource files needed by every sample 
            is located here.  
			
[src]       Source code of samples and the RebeccaAIML 
            engine if you downloaded the source code.

If you have the source code distribution you have 
a few extra added directories of:

[src/rebecca]           Source code of the engine			  

[include/rebecca/impl]  Header files only needed for building
                        the engine.			  

------------------------------------------------------------------
			   
ENJOY and don't hesitate to email with questions, problems, or
suggestions on how to improve this project!
			   

GIT'd By: Drake Justice: hallowname@gmail.com (no flame please)

name: sizzle
readme:
This is a new pure-JavaScript CSS selector engine that I'm working on.

Comes in at roughly 4x faster in Firefox 3, 3x faster in Opera 9, 1.5x faster in Safari 3 than the other major JavaScript libraries. It's completely standalone (no library dependencies) and clocks in at 4KB.

Currently this engine is expected to become the new default selector engine of jQuery, MochiKit, Prototype, and Dojo. Please contact me if you're interested in working on integrating Sizzle into your library.

commit.message:
IE8 freaks out when you access out-of-bounds properties on the NodeSet,
provided a workaround.

Removed an unnecessary line which was causing problems with class
filters.
Fixed an issue with how the IE comment handling was working.
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:jeresig/sizzle
Added a fix for handling comment nodes from gEBTN("*") in IE.
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:jeresig/sizzle
Tweaked the speed test suite to run more times.
Tweaked the selector tests (there was disagreement between browsers as to if :enabled should make [type=hidden] elements, or not - not a huge issue, imo).
Tweaked the copyright header.
Provided a fallback for attributes that aren't immediately available in the DOM.
Changed to using 'root' instead of 'head' (which is a more appropriate name).
Positional selectors weren't handling multi-selectors properly "div:first, div:last".

Completely re-worked how positional selectors are handled (e.g. :first, :last, etc.). They were handled within the context of an individual query before rather than from a top-down manner which users expect.
Modifed the test file to pull in the jQuery/Sizzle hybrid file.
Fixed an issue where makeArray wasn't appending items to an existing array in makeArray - only if a proper array was passed in.
Fixed ~= to work on space-separated values, not just doing a match.
The head element doesn't exist in documents that don't explictly define one in WebKit - use documentElement instead (still works).
Selectors with no context (thus defaulting to a context of document) was causing errors when a .contextDocument was used (which is null on document).
Removed browser-specific checks for handling makeArray and the getElementById(someName) problems.
Minor tweak to the *-child caching code.
Added support for Sizzle("> div", context) (along with + and ~ as well).

Tweaked the getElementsByClassName detection code to look for the method on the documentElement (which makes sure that custom implementations that are slapped on in browsers, like IE, aren't detected).
Tweaked the contains function to have a generic definition.
Fixing a bug where inline filters were stopping filtering too early.
Fixed an issue with ":first-child > *" (documentElement was getting picked up, which doesn't have a parent, causing problems for the CHILD filters).
Fixed a bug with psuedo-selectors sometimes getting munged by position selectors.
Make the qSA detection more generic. Should eventually move to using qSA on any element.
Added support for a new Sizzle.matches method which takes an expression and an array of elements - which are filtered based upon the expression.
Expose the old jQuery API for adding in :foo selectors.
Forgot to restore the selectors object after qSA is introduced.
Forced contextual selectors (Sizzle("div", document.body)) to have the full selector be contained within the context.
Added more features to the jQuery-specific Sizzle code - now serves as a complete drop-in replacement for the existing src/selector.js file in jQuery.
Make sure that the context actually is a DOM element or DOM document.

Moved the library-specific code outside of Sizzle and added an extra build script to add it back
in again.
No longer expose window.Sizzle if a library already exists. Also expose Expr as Sizzle.selectors.
Landing an improvement to .class performance.
Improved the performance of "div > p", "div, p", and "div p" selectors.
Reorganized the directional search code (resulting in less function calls).
Added the MIT license and copyright notice to the sizzle.js file.
Added the MIT license to the code.
Updated the performance testing frameworks.
Updated the readme to be more current.
Tweaked the caching code (saves an array copy, instead of the original).

Sizzle now passes all tests in IE 6, Firefox 3, and Safari 3.1. (One test fails in Firefox 3.1, one test fails in Opera 9.51)

Fixed:
- Fixed more cases of erroneous ID override in IE.
- .substr(-1) doesn't work in IE.
- Do extra checks to make sure metadata is only added to specific elements.
Typo in .length commit fix.
Fixed the .length bug in Internet Explorer (elements with a id of length overwrite the .length property of NodeSets).
Fixed the case where elem[doesntExist] occurred (would throw a syntax error).
Fxied a bug with attribute selectors. Selectors like "div[class^=exa][class$=mple]" now work properly.
Use more strict equality checks - fixed an issue with .toUpperCase in :button.

Added in a bunch of selectors that are commonly used by jQuery and MochiKit (left out :hidden and :visible - should be handled by the library). Fixed the return result of Sizzle when qSA is used (was a NodeList, should be an array). Implemented proper |= support.
querySelectorAll wasn't being used in the case of Sizzle("div") since , document wasn't passed in.
Tweaked the code to make sure that a new array is returned for cached selectors.
Fixed a couple minor bugs in the selector code.
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:jeresig/sizzle
Adding a explanatory README file.
Trailing comma.
Landing the initial version of Sizzle.

name: acts_as_state_machine
readme:
= Acts As State Machine

This act gives an Active Record model the ability to act as a finite state
machine (FSM).

Acquire via subversion at:

http://elitists.textdriven.com/svn/plugins/acts_as_state_machine/trunk

If prompted, use the user/pass anonymous/anonymous.

== Example

 class Order < ActiveRecord::Base
   acts_as_state_machine :initial => :opened

   state :opened
   state :closed, :enter => Proc.new {|o| Mailer.send_notice(o)}
   state :returned

   event :close do
     transitions :to => :closed, :from => :opened
   end

   event :return do
     transitions :to => :returned, :from => :closed
   end
 end

 o = Order.create
 o.close! # notice is sent by mailer
 o.return!

name: giftsmas
description: Gift Tracking Website using Roda and Sequel
readme:
= Giftsmas

Giftsmas is a web application designed for keeping track of gifts people
receive during an event.  It is designed around a moderate size family
keeping track of all gifts that any member of the family received for
Christmas.

== Demo

If you just want to play around with a demo, go to http://giftsmas-demo.jeremyevans.net
and login with demo/demo.

== Command line setup

After cloning the repository from github, switch to the giftsmas directory:

  cd /path/to/giftsmas

Install the necessary gems from the Gemfile using bundler or rubygems.

Create the db and run the migration:

  createdb giftsmas
  sequel -m migrate postgres:///giftsmas

Create your user(s):

  irb -I. -rmodels
  irb(main):001:0> User.create(:name=>'...', :password=>'...')

Modify the configuration for the server, if necessary:

  $EDITOR config.ru 

Start the server:

  rackup
  
== The web interface

Giftsmas, when run with rackup, runs on port 9292 by default (you can modify this in
config.ru).  So open up your webbrowser:

  $BROWSER http://localhost:9292
  
It will redirect you to the login page.  Put in a username and password that
you created earlier and click "Login".  It will ask you to create an event.
Choose an event name and click "Create New Event".  It will put you on the add
gift page.  Put in a gift name, sender name(s), and receiver name(s) and click
"Add Gift".  It will add the gift to the database and put you back at the add
gift page, but this time you'll have checkboxes for the senders and receivers
you entered.  If you want to use a sender or receiver that's not in one of
the select boxes, type the name in (you can separate names with a comma).  This
is true even if you want to use a sender or receiver that doesn't have a
checkbox (you can always type in the names, it doesn't create duplicates).

== Other pages

=== Event

* Associate Receivers: You can use this to associate other people as possible
  receivers in the current event (so they show up in the receivers select box
  on the add gift page).  Mostly useful if you have multiple events and most
  of the people in this event were also in a previous event.
* Associate Senders: Same as Associate Receivers, but for senders.
* Change Event: Change the currently used event, either by picking another
  event or adding a new event.

=== Reports

* In Chronological Order: Simple report listing all gifts received in
  chronological order.
* By Receiver: Gives separate reports for each receiver.  When printing the
  reports, uses one page per receiver.
* By Sender: Similar to By Receiver, but for senders.
* Summary: Shows the total number of gifts, as well as totals by sender
  and receiver.
* Summary Crosstab: Shows for each sender/receiver pair, how many gifts the
  sender gave the receiver.
* Thank You Notes: Gives separate reports for each receiver, showing gifts
  received from people who weren't receivers at the event.  When printing
  the reports, uses one page per receiver.
  
=== Other

This are simple scaffold pages for changing data in the database.  You can
use them to rename an event, person, or gift, to modify senders/receivers
of gifts after they have been added, or to delete gifts.
 
== Running the specs

=== Prerequisites to run the specs

* rake
* rspec 1.3+
* capybara

=== Setup

Create the db and run the migration:

  createdb giftsmas_test
  sequel -m /path/to/giftsmas/migrate postgres:///giftsmas_test

== Running the specs

The specs are run with rake:

  rake spec # Unit tests
  rake integration # Integration tests
  rake # Both
  
== License

Giftsmas is released under the MIT License.  See the LICENSE file for details.

== Author

Jeremy Evans <code@jeremyevans.net>

name: jquery-google-analytics
description: A Google Analytics plugin for jQuery. Improves page load times. Simplifies link and event tracking.
readme:
h1. jQuery Google Analytics Plugin NOTE This plugin hasn't been updated to work with the latest version of Google Analytics. I recommend you fork and improve the code and submit a patch. h2. Introduction The jQuery Google Analytics plugin does the following: * improves page load times by deferring the loading of Google Analytics to after the page has been loaded. (Note Google is currently testing their own implementation which does the same) * simplifies event and link tracking. * helps you track error pages (404, 500) as described "here":http://www.google.com/support/analytics/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=86927. h2. Installation h3. JavaScript Inside the head tag, first include the jQuery JavaScript file, then the jQuery Google Analytics file:
h3. Usage With the script loaded you now have access to these new methods: * $.trackPage('UA-XXX-XXX') - Adds Google Analytics tracking to the page it's called from. By default, the loading of Google analytics is done after the onload event. * $.('selector').track - Used in combination with jQuery selectors to add click tracking, or tracking of other jQuery events, to matching elements. For example: $('selector').track() * $.trackEvent - Used for custom event tracking. Same as _pageTracker.trackEvent, but checks that analytics isn't blocked. For example: $.trackEvent('category', 'action', 'label') h4. Page tracking To enable Google Analytics page tracking add a call to $.trackPage inside the head tag:
To improve page load times, the script defers the loading of the Google Analytics script to after the page has been loaded (window.onload). To disable this feature, set the onload parameter to false:
h5. Tracking 404 and 500 errors This plugin implements tracking of error pages "as described on the Google Analytics Help pages":http://www.google.com/support/analytics/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=86927 To track an error, simply set the status_code parameter to the response code, as shown in this example:
h4. Link tracking Link tracking is done by selecting the elements you want to track with jQuery selectors. By default the click event is tracked, but this can be changed as I'll explain later. The following is an example of how to track outgoing links (to also track internal links, set the skip_internal parameter to false):
The first example selects links in the sidebar and sets the category to 'sidebar'. The second example selects links in the footer and sets the category to 'footer'. The third example selects links located inside the "complex div" and uses the link's class as category. See index.html for complete examples. h4. Custom event tracking You can also track events by calling the trackEvent method:
h4. Parameters The track methods accepts the following parameters: * "category":http://code.google.com/apis/analytics/docs/eventTrackerGuide.html#Categories - required string used to group events. Default is autodetected: internal or external. * "action":http://code.google.com/apis/analytics/docs/eventTrackerGuide.html#Actions - required string used to define event type, eg. click, download. Default is click. * "label":http://code.google.com/apis/analytics/docs/eventTrackerGuide.html#Labels - optional label to attach to event, eg. buy. Default is href attribute's value. * "value":http://code.google.com/apis/analytics/docs/eventTrackerGuide.html#Values - optional numerical value to attach to event, eg. price. Default null. Additional parameters supported by the track(), not the trackEvent(), method: * skip_internal - Default true. If true then internal links are not tracked. * event_name - Default click. Name of the event to track. The following snippet shows you how to define the parameters:
If no parameters are given then sensible defaults are used, which should work in most cases. Note that you can also use functions instead of string values. Functions are useful for extracting the values from the HTML itself (metadata). h4. Tracking mouseover and other events The default behavior is to track the click event. This can be changed to any other jQuery event by setting the *event_name* parameter to the name of the event you want to track, as shown in this example:
h4. Debugging You can print debug statements to the Firebug console by setting the debug option. Default: false. To enable: $.fn.track.defaults.debug = true; h2. Todo * Review code * Refactor code h2. Author "Christian Hellsten":http://christianhellsten.com ("Aktagon Ltd.":http://aktagon.com) h3. Contributors "Joshua Jabbour":http://joshuajabbour.com

issue.title: Add support for e-commerce tracking
issue.body:
As in http://code.google.com/apis/analytics/docs/gaJS/gaJSApiEcommerce.html

That would be very nice indeed. Not too complicated. 

I propose adding one methode trackPurchase() that takes a collection of items plus the an object containing the transaction information and takes care of all the calls necessary to register that transaction.

issue.title: custom vars functionality for the plugin
Middle clicks NOT tracked?
issue.body:
Just as (in Windows platform web browsers) you can open a link in a new window by CTRL-left-clicking, you can also middle(mousebutton)-click a link to do exactly the same thing, and I had always assumed that both cases were treated identically by Google Analytics, and thus by your plugin.

However, having just spent some considerable time in Firebug, I have realised that my assumptions are false - middle-clicks are NOT tracked!

Is it possible to ensure that left-clicks and middle-clicks ARE both tracked without having to duplicate my calls to your plugin - i.e. to avoid having to initialise once for the [left]click event, and once for the middle-click event? Can you create a new option to allow this behaviour to be switched on, just as debugging can?

And can you please make it clearer to other potential users that middle-clicks are not tracked by default?

name: typo
description: The famous Ruby on Rails blog engine
readme:
What is it?
===========

Typo is a weblog system written in Ruby using Ruby on Rails. Weblogs are cool,
weblogs are "in" and everyone who writes code has an different opinion on how
a weblog should be written. Typo is our take on it. Typo is designed to be
usable by programmers and non-programmers, while being easy for programmers to
extend.

Requirements
============

Currently you need all of those things to get typo to run:

 * Ruby 1.8.6 or Ruby Enterprise Edition. 
 * Rails 2.2, Typo 5.2 DOES NOT support Rails 2.1.
 * A database.  Typo supports MySQL, PostgreSQL, and SQLite.
 * Ruby drivers for your database.
 * For best performance, you should have a web server running either
   Apache, Lighttpd or Nginx, along with FastCGI, mongrel or thin. You can use 
   Ruby's built-in web server for low-volume testing.
   We recommend the use of Apache + mod_rails (aka Passenger) for fast and 
   easy deployment along with speed.
 * rspec, rcov and ruby-debug are necessary to run the test suit.

Installation
============

See doc/Installer.text and doc/typo-5.2-release-notes.txt.

Usage
======

Typo's administrative interface is available at
http://your.domain.com/admin. You can use this to post articles and
change Typo's configuration settings. For posting new content, you can
either use this administrative web interface or a desktop blog editor
like MarsEdit or Ecto. For a short list of clients which are confirmed
to work please visit http://typosphere.org/wiki/DesktopClients.

Client setup
============

Set your desktop client to Movable Type API and enter
http://your.domain.com/backend/xmlrpc as endpoint address.

Enjoy,
Your typo team

Mark auth_token cookie as :http_only

An attacker who manages to capture the auth_token cookie can log into Typo
without a password.  By marking the auth_token cookie as :http_only, we
instruct modern browsers to restrict JavaScript access to the auth_token
cookie (though some browsers ignore this instruction, and other browsers
make the cookie available via XmlHttpRequest).

Fixing onhover: Add typo_user_profile cookie (and fix auth_token)

I'm trying to re-enable the [Edit], etc., links on posts and comments.
These were implemented using JavaScript.  Originally, the JavaScript
checked the is_admin cookie, which was removed when roles were added to
Typo in fcbcefc16b149a7b5de16ed4ac75c9bb9cd79524.  This patch replaces the
old is_admin cookie with a new typo_user_profile cookie indicating what
type of account the user has.  The JavaScript portion of this new feature
will be included in a future patch.

Note that we also add code to clear the auth_token cookie on logout.

Instead of having merge_... and extract_... methods, let's just make this a
virtual field.  This requires changing the field name in the view, too, but

Fix various issues in new-style extended content handling

Once upon a time, the Typo web interface allowed you to separately edit the
"body" and the "extended content" of an article.  Now, the two different
types of text are stored in a single body field, and separated by
"<!--more-->".  This change has not yet been pushed through to the
underlying database.

This patch doesn't attempt to address any of the larger design or
implementation issues, but it does fix a number of minor problems:

  - The build_extended and get_extended methods on ContentController were
    public, which actually made them callable for users on the web.  This
    kind of helper method should generally be protected or private in a
    controller.
  - The build_extended method would silently discard data if the user
    accidentally inserted two copies of '<!--more-->' in an article.
  - The build_extended method didn't remove the newlines inserted by the
    get_extended method, which would cause the article to pick up two extra
    newlines each time it was saved.

The patch moves the merging/extracting code into the article model, fixes
the data-loss bug, makes sure that articles can be edited without any
inadvertent changes, and adds a number of unit tests to make sure that
everything works.

Ignore SQLite3 databases, schema.rb and Emacs backup files

Here are three proposed additions to .gitignore.  Please feel free to pick
and choose:

  db/*.sqlite3: Ignore SQLite3 databases.
  db/schema.rb: This file is automatically generated, and not currently
    checked into the Typo git repository.  So we might as well ignore
    it for now.
  *~: Ignore Emacs backup files.

Fix spec warnings in CommentsControllerSpec

This specification file triggered two warnings because it contained
confused mocking code.  This patch fixes the spec to set the mock objects
up correctly.

With this patch, the unit tests should now be completely clean.

Fix MetaWeblog API to interpret time zones consistently

The goal of this patch is to fix the following unit test failure, which
started occuring at (IIRC) 7pm Eastern Standard Time this evening:

  Test::Unit::AssertionFailedError in 'BackendController
    test_meta_weblog_new_post'
  <Fri Nov 28 05:00:00 UTC 2008> expected but was
  <Sat Nov 29 05:00:00 UTC 2008>.
  ./spec/controllers/backend_controller_spec.rb:186:in
    `test_meta_weblog_new_post'

This failure does not occur earlier in the day, at least in my time zone.

To fix this problem, we need to fix the dateCreated field returned by
getPost to use a proper dateTime value instead of a string.  This may
affect users who use MetaWeblog API clients, though hopefully it will only
affect them for the better.

The problem: The existing code is attempting to use UTC for all dateTime
values, but failing, because it sometimes returns strings where dateTime
values are expected.

Why the existing code is correct to _attempt_ to use UTC everywhere:

The XML-RPC spec does not allow serialized dateTime values to contain a
time zone, and instead relies on clients and servers to agree on a
convention for interpreting dateTime values:

  http://www.xmlrpc.com/spec

  * What timezone should be assumed for the dateTime.iso8601 type? UTC?
    localtime?

    Don't assume a timezone. It should be specified by the server in its
    documentation what assumptions it makes about timezones.

As you can see from the following discussion, the MetaWeblog API inherits
this ambiguity:

  http://www.25hoursaday.com/weblog/CommentView.aspx?guid=c210531e-646c-41e8-a81e-f3efd4ba8df4

As noted in that comment thread, most blogging tools have standardized on
using UTC everywhere, since it can be unambiguously interpreted without a
timezone.

The fixes:

  1) First, in the test cases, Time.now.midnight.utc and
     Time.now.utc.midnight are _not_ the same in most time zones.  This is
     fixed by relying on the previously computed value of
     'article.published_at' instead of checking the clock a second time.
     Doing this also allows us to work around a hypothetical test case
     failure which would occur if the clock passed midnight in the middle
     of the test case.

  2) Second, ActionWebService will simply Do The Right Thing with dates,
     but only if it can identify them as such.  Previously, the function
     MetaWeblogService.article_dto_from would actually try to serialize
     dates as strings instead of XML-RPC dateTime values.  This caused a
     variety of time zone lossage, and made the test case failures very
     hard to debug.  The biggest consequence of this bug: getPost would
     return a string instead of an XML-RPC dateTime value for dateCreated.

I've added a test case to make sure that we can round-trip dates without
corrupting them.

Fix spec failures in accounts_controller_spec.rb

It looks like some of these unit tests haven't been run in a while.  The
fix for 'renders the logout action' was simple--the underlying code had
been changed without changing the test suite.

The fix for the logout tests was a bit trickier.  Apparently, the
LoginSystem code in vendor/plugins/typo_login_system uses session[:user],
while the accounts controller uses session[:user_id].  We need to make sure
that both of these get set up correctly.  But doing this necessitates some
other, related changes.

Prevent accidentally changing the blog's title

When running the unit tests, I was getting the following error:

  Test::Unit::AssertionFailedError in 'BackendController
    test_blogger_get_users_blogs'
  <"test blog trackbacks trackbacks"> expected but was
    <"test blog">.
  ./spec/controllers/backend_controller_spec.rb:37:in
    `test_blogger_get_users_blogs'

First problem: This error message has accidentally reversed the expected and
actual values.

Second problem: The following two lines in xml_controller.rb were
accidentally changing the blog title.  This occurs because '<<' actually
updates a string in place.

  @feed_title = this_blog.blog_name
  ...
  @feed_title << " trackbacks"

The fix: Make a copy of the blog title before storing it in @feed_title.

Fix mocking of published articles for GroupingController

Once upon a time, I suspect that GroupingController called
grouping.published_articles to generate the list of published articles.
But currently, it calls:

  @articles =
    grouping.articles.paginate(:page => params[:page],
                               :conditions => { :published => true })

This means that the specs for our three major types of groupings need to
override grouping.articles instead of grouping.published_articles when
setting up their mocks.  There's some regretable code duplication among the
various spec files, so this had to be fixed in three places.

There's also a larger philosophical issue with published_articles.
Currently, it has no callers outside of the various spec/**/*.rb files, and
it is defined in a variety of inconsistent ways.  See the following bug for
further discussion of what to do here:

  http://typosphere.org/projects/typo/issues/show?id=1294

Fix table row count in categories_controller_spec.rb

There are actually two "header" rows in this table before the categories.

Fix spec failures in article_closing_spec.rb

This is another case of Blog.default caching a blog before the specs get a
chance to set it up properly.  So, as before, we just stub it.  This fixes
two more spec failures, bringing the total down to 8.

Include ContentHelper into content_helper_spec.rb

This no longer gets included automatically.  Fixing this takes care of
another 2 failures, bringing the total down to 10.

Fix spec failure in comment_spec.rb test_default_filter

The test_default_filter method was checking the default filter:

  def test_default_filter
    a = Comment.find(:first)
    assert_equal 'markdown', a.default_text_filter.name
  end

But this was failing, because the underlying value was getting scrambled by
test_xss_rejection and not restored properly.  This patch fixes 1 unit test
failure, bringing the total to 12.

Fix spec failures in comments_controller_spec.rb

The unit tests weren't always picking up the mock @blog correctly, so I
added the following line to their setup.  This fixes 4 unit-test failures
in my copy:

  Blog.stub!(:default).and_return(@blog)

We were already stubbing Blog.find, but that wasn't enough:

  Blog.stub!(:find).and_return(@blog)

As far as I can tell, the results of Blog.find were being cached too soon
by Blog.default, and picking up a value from the database instead of our
mock:

  # The default Blog.  This is the lowest-numbered blog, almost always id==1.
  def self.default
    @@default ||= find(:first, :order => 'id')
  rescue
    logger.warn 'You have not Blog install.'
    nil
  end

So by stubbing Blog.default, we make sure that the unit test always sees
our mock.

Update bundled coderay gem to use new 'rake gems' infrastructure

The bundled coderay gem was causing a number of errors on application
startup (and when running rake tasks).

  config.gem: Unpacked gem coderay in vendor/gems has no specification
    file. Run 'rake gems:refresh_specs' to fix this.
  config.gem: Unpacked gem coderay in vendor/gems not in a versioned
    directory. Giving up.

Unfortunately, 'rake gems:refresh_specs' wouldn't work, because coderay
didn't have a "versioned directory".  A versioned directory has a name of
the form:

  vendor/gems/mygem-VERSION

The easiest way to manage gems in Rails 2.2.2 is to use 'config.gem'
statements in environment.rb.  So I added the appropriate line to
environment.rb and ran:

  rake gems:unpack

You can see the status of all declared gems using 'rake gems', and there
are a variety of useful rake tasks for working with these declarations.

I haven't touched anything else in the vendor/ directory, because
everything else works as-is with Rails 2.2.2.

Fixes 2 nasty bugs with autosave
 the first one broke autosave when no title was set. We now set a default title
 the second one was overriding permalink with a void string when post was autosaved because the permalink field was empty after autosave.

For autosave: If no title is given, Typo gives it a title like "Article Draft + post_id". When publishing, every article-draft-something permalink is just replaced with the article title crafted permalink.

git-svn-id: http://svn.typosphere.org/typo/trunk@1647 820eb932-12ee-0310-9ca8-eeb645f39767

Hah! Take that you lousy cache monster!

We no longer attempt to sweep the cache 99 times per request when
changing blog settings. All the cache deletions are saved up until
the end of the request so if BlogSweeper#expire_for gets called 
multiple times, the cache still only gets swept once.

Which is nice.

I've turned caching on in the development environment for the time 
being too - I want the debug level logging, and I want to hit problems
quickly when I'm testing rather than discovering them in a production
log.

git-svn-id: http://svn.typosphere.org/typo/trunk@1621 820eb932-12ee-0310-9ca8-eeb645f39767

Giving tests and fixtures some love.

Moving from explicit ids throughout the fixtures and many of the tests to taking
advantage of the new fixture capabilities in Rails 2. 

We're now loading _all_ the fixtures from test_helper, which should hopefully
reduce problems we've been experiencing with test ordering, which is nice.

Eventually, I intend to move to using pre_loaded_fixtures - loading the fixtures
up as part of the initial rake task, and then letting transactional rollback
stuff deal with the rest.

Much footling with the feedback state machine and various 
caching related things.

I ''think'' cache sweeping should now be happening in all the 
right places, while being reasonably light on the CPU and memory.

If you do come across cases where the cache isn't being emptied
when it should, please let me know <pdcawley-typo@bofh.org.uk>
or raise a ticket here and we'll look into it.

Also, we've reinstated fragment caching; page caching comes with 
a whole host of gotchas that I'd rather not think about just now.


git-svn-id: http://svn.typosphere.org/typo/trunk@1511 820eb932-12ee-0310-9ca8-eeb645f39767

Right ho, /articles/category now redirects to /articles/categories, 
which is a resource now.

Eventually, CategoriesController will take on the duties of 
Admin::CategoriesController, but not quite yet, for now it just handles
index and show.

Note that we've also introduced a new type of resource, the 'inflected_resource'
which uses /articles/categories/... for its collection methods, but 
/articles/category/whatever for its members. This means that you we can 
have a category with a permalink of 'new' and it won't clash with with the 
admin form for creating a new category.

Isn't that lovely?
